column2: Bathing water surveys, UK Guideline Standards - Percentage compliance
Department of the Environment (Northern Ireland) (DoE(NI)), Environment Agency (EA), Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA)
Environment Statistics Service, Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, Area 6E Ergon House, 17 Smith Square, London SW1P 3JR, 08459 33 55 77
Bathing waters which are closed for a season are excluded for that year
At least 80 per cent of samples must have counts not exceeding the guideline limit values for total and faecal coliforms, and at least 90 per
cent of samples must have counts not exceeding the guideline limit values for faecal streptococci. Must also pass the mandatory standard.
Inland bathing waters were identified for the first time in 1998.
In 2009, regions with identified inland bathing water sites were: Scotland (3), Thames (6) and North West (3).
Data are only shown for years and regions where all sites have monitored faecal streptococci. Except for the South West in 1991, when
there were no faecal stretococci samples taken at Bournemouth Hengistbury West. The bathing water has not been included in the
(a)  Thames and Southern was consildated into South East for the 2011 figures and percentage compliance backcast and re-calculated til 2007
